results.title: Entree Jacques
results.creator_credit: SBS-TV, Media World, John Tatoulis, Colin South and Paul Sime
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Changing Australia”.
Jacques Reymond, chef extraordinaire, came to Australia at the invitation of James Halliday and was so impressed by the quality of our produce and lifestyle that he has become an Australian. As the winner of a competition between Australia’s top chefs he was asked to prepare a meal using all Australian produce for an international competition in London. As he prepares for this event he visits the producers of his ingredients and talks about trends in Australian food. “Foodies” Rita Ehrlich, Terry Durack, Jill Dupleix and Kevin Donovan also participate.

results.title: Entree des Artistes = the Curtain Rises
results.brief_description:
Entree des Artistes’ details the lives and loves of several students at the Paris Conservatory of Drama. Wealthy student Cecilia is in love with fellow student Francois and jealous of his relationship with poor student Isabelle. Cecilia successfully plots to break-up the relationship. As the end of the presentation approaches, Cecilia decides to play the part of a woman who dies of poisoning. Of particular interest in this film is the ‘real-life’ scene in which Louis Jouvet plays his own role as a teacher at the Paris Drama School rehearsing young actor Bernard Blier.

Credits: Producer, Georges Jouanne ; director, Marc Allegret ; writers, Henri Jeanson, Andre Cayatte ; photography, Christian Matras, Robert Juillard ; music, Georges Auric ; art direction, Jacques Krauss, Alexandre Trauner.
Cast: Louis Jouvet, Janine Darcey, Claude Dauphin, Odette Joyeux, Andre Brunot, Mady Made, Julien Carette, Marcel Dalio, Sylvie, Roger Blin, Bernard Blier, Michel Vitold.

results.title: Entr'acte
results.brief_description: A humorous cinematic poem attempting to capture all the images and associations of carnival, which dissolve into each other in the dreams of a young man who has just returned from an evening at the fair. There is no plot, each image suggesting the one to follow. This is one of the most celebrated of French avant-garde films. Made originally for a ballet called “Relache” (i.e. performance suspended) it was thus a joke within a joke - an entr’acte or intermission in a non-existent performance. No spoken word, this film’s story was written by Francis Picabia with music by Erik Satie

results.title: Entombed warriors
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Rob McAuley and Bob Kingsbury

results.title: Enthronement of the Archbishop of York
results.brief_description: Some of the recordings made at the enthronement of Archbishop Coggan in York Minster from the arrival of the Archbishop through to his installation and enthronement. Some explanation of cathedral traditions is given in the commentary.

results.title: Enthalpy (TEFC)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Structure Bonding and the Periodic Law”.
Professor Haynes of Open University explains the procedures involved in the National Physical Laboratory’s equipment to determine enthalpy changes. The process is compared to home/school laboratory calorimeters and used to discuss the theory of and problems associated with measuring energy changes in chemical reactions.

results.title: Entertainment storytelling
results.creator_credit: KTV Productions, John A. Givins and Lynn John
results.brief_description:
Episode number 15 of Series “Video tech”.
This program allows the viewer to consolidate what they have learned in the other episodes of the series and apply these to the production of an entertainment story. Follow the production of an actual story from the initial stages of choosing and developing an idea, researching the background, planning work which has to be done on the shoot, getting the shots needed for the story, shotlisting, and doing an interview through to post-production and the screening of the final product.
results.creator_credit_for_label: KTV Productions, John A. Givins and Lynn John

results.title: Entertainment
results.creator_credit: ABC-TV (Australia), Griffith University, Asian Studies Council and Robin James
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Dragons tongue. - Series 2.”.
In this Chinese language program, Professor Colin Mackerras looks at recreational activities in China. Cinema going is particularly popular and European and American films are being shown more frequently. The Peking Opera is a much loved and traditional art form, steeped in cultural heritage. Although it is not as popular amongst young Chinese, tourists love the rich pageantry. The Chinese also love outdoor events in parks and on waterways. The composition of Chinese characters in Chinese writing is also examined.

results.title: Entertaining with Isabel Jones
results.brief_description: Isabelle Jones, cookery broadcaster and journalist, shows you step-by-step how simple cooking and entertaining really is. This 60-minute video features four different menus for six people. Over 25 tried and tested, delicious recipes in the accompanying cover booklet. Table setting ideas, lots of cooking tips, quick and easy methods. Rated: G

results.title: Entertaining Mr. Sloane
results.creator_credit: Canterbury Film Productions, Douglas Kentish and Douglas Hickox
results.brief_description: Joe Orton’s plays eroticised the “kitchen-sink” realist theatre of the 1960s. In “Entertaining Mr. Sloane” a young man lodges with a safely bourgeois brother and sister (Harry Edwards and Beryl Reid) only to find that they are both interested in seducing him, and they will let nothing get in their way of satisfying their sexual desires. Though it is as theatre that Orton’s work is most successful, this film is still a satisfying translation of his work onto the screen. The cast is magnificent, especially the wonderful Beryl Reid.
